subject: Re: JUnit considered problematic
msgSnippet: ... DBC is not about testing. Not even Mr. Bertrand Meyer (the inventor of DBC) claims that. If you wanted to test correctnes of implementatio with DBC you
messageBody:
> Testing of the code (methods) can be done with precondition,
> invartiants and postconditions (the contracts). Thats how I
> understand Design by Contract.

DBC is not about testing. Not even Mr. Bertrand Meyer (the inventor
of DBC) claims that. If you wanted to test correctnes of
implementatio with DBC you would have to duplicate a function's
algorithm - or an equivalent one - in its postcondition. Tests don't
suffer from that dilemma since tests can work with samples.

> Now the great thing: When you compile your code the implementation
> can be checked whether it obeys the contract.

DBC is not about compile time verification but about runtime checks.
Code verification has some relationship to DBC but is a different
field of research.

> If not, a compile error
> is thrown. That it!

No, that's not what happens when using DBC.

> I am not satisfied with the JUnit and TDD "paradigma". They are
> originated because of a *poverty* in Java programing language. If
> Java would support proper Design by Contract and a compiler for
that
> than no one would bother with JUnit and TDD.

Any reason for EiffelUnit to exist then?
(http://freshmeat.net/projects/eiffelunit)

Johannes
